Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Advances in Catalysis Symposium in the 2015 International Advances in Functional Materials Conference; Stony Brook, NY

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1546648
Kim, Tae Jin

The proposal supports travel and registration costs for graduate and undergraduate students from United States universities attending the Advances in Catalysis Symposium that will be held as part of the 2015 International Advances in Functional Materials (AFM) Conference from June 29-July 3, 2015 at SUNY Stony Brook in Stony Brook, NY. The funds sought in this proposal will be used to defray travel and registration costs for approximately 10 graduate and undergraduate students from United States institutions.

The catalyst symposium and related talks will provide students an opportunity to learn about the most recent advances in the field of catalysis, as well as emerging areas of research and technological interest. They will also have an opportunity to present their own research findings and discuss results with other students and established experts in the field. Catalysis is an important enabling technology for many pressing economic and societal needs, including energy sustainability, chemical manufacturing and petroleum refining, shale gas processing, and environmental protection. Conference participation will help train the next generation of catalytic scientists and engineers, and also inspire undergraduate students to pursue careers in the area of catalysis, thus ensuring a well-trained workforce to meet growing demands in the catalysis area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2015 International Advanced in Functional Materials conference was held at Stony Brook University (Student Activities Center and Charles B. Wang Center), NY, on June 29 – July 3, 2015. Figure 1 shows the conference brochure which included detailed information of the AFM international conference. 

World-renowned senior scientists gave a lecture as plenary and keynote speakers and discussed the role of functional materials, such as catalysts, in the current and future energy and environment related developments. AFM conference organization invited 2 plenary speakers and 14 keynote speaker (listed in Appendix A) from around the world (U.S.A, U.K, China, South Korea, Spain, and Saudi Arabia) and ~ 400 speakers (oral and poster) attended the conference. Especially, three senior women scientists (prof. Esther Takeuchi, prof. Perena Gouma, and prof. Miriam Rafailvich) were keynote speakers, who gave a strong scientific motivation to young women scientists, especially early-career scientists and students. Graduate and postdoctoral students participated in the symposium as an oral or poster presenter, while undergraduate students attended as volunteers [Figure 2]. 

Because catalysis research play a key role in the current world economy and energy market, conference organization provided what catalysts synthesis methods and characterization techniques are required to overcome the current energy and environmental issues. In addition to aforementioned two catalysis areas, conference also provided how computational methodologies can predict a chemical reaction over homogeneous/heterogeneous/bio-mimic catalysts and can support an experiment result. During the conference and symposium, attendees obtained an overall and a detailed knowledge of catalysis research from world-renowned plenary (Prof. Robert Howard Grubbs) and keynote speakers (Prof. Israel E Wachs, Prof. Jean Marie Basset, Prof. Miguel A. Bañares, Dr. Jose Rodriguez, and Dr. Rajeev S. Assary). During the plenary and keynote speakers’ lecture, speakers covered 1) catalysts synthesis, 2) characterization, and 3) computational modeling, thus attendees especially early-career researchers had an excellent opportunity to learn advance technology in most catalysis research areas. [Figure 3]

The Advances in Catalysis symposium integrated the catalysis research scientists from academia, national laboratory and industry to discuss the catalysts impact on fuels, chemicals, and environment. Research collaborations (Domestic/International and Experiment/Theory group) were expected during and after the symposium periods to address current fundamental and application catalysis in chemical engineering, chemistry, materials science and physics.

Students (undergraduate, graduate, and post doctor) and early-career scientists participated in the poster sessions (132 posters presentation) and had a chance to discuss the next generation of catalysis and advances functional materials with senior faculties and scientists. [Figure 4] 

This opportunity provided valuable experiences to young scientists to develop their careers in catalysis and materials science research areas. Especially, conference organization emphasized and dedicated to encourage minority and women in science and engineering to participate in the symposium. Awarded NSF grants supported 10 undergraduate and graduate students for the conference registration, accommodation, and poster competition participation. After completion of the symposium, the collected papers were published Materials Today: Proceedings through peer review process. (Materials Today: Proceeding, Volume 3, Issue 2, Advances in Functional Materials (Conference 2015)) (http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/ journal/22147853/3/2)
